message.content:
We first need to compute some averages and then use the formulas below. Note that in our calculations, when a beginning balance is provided (and it is zero for Accounts Receivable) we compute the average as (Beginning + Ending)/2.

Step 1. Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio  
• Formula: (Total Revenue) ÷ (Average Accounts Receivable)  
• Here, Total Revenue = 5,064,939.23  
• Beginning Accounts Receivable = 0.00 and Ending Accounts Receivable = 1,851,327.29  
  ⇒ Average AR = (0.00 + 1,851,327.29) / 2 = 925,663.645  
• Ratio = 5,064,939.23 ÷ 925,663.645 ≈ 5.47  

Step 2. Operating Cash Flow Ratio (and Operating Cash Flow to Current Liabilities Ratio)  
• We use the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities and Current Liabilities.  
• Here, Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = –64,099.10  
• Total Current Liabilities at end = 1,493,246.99  
• Ratio = –64,099.10 ÷ 1,493,246.99 ≈ –0.04293, which can be rounded to –0.04  
• (In the sample problem these two ratios are the same.)  

Step 3. Total Asset Turnover Ratio  
• Formula: (Total Revenue) ÷ (Average Total Assets)  
• Total Assets at beginning = 13,000,000.00 and at end = 15,200,446.16  
  ⇒ Average Total Assets = (13,000,000.00 + 15,200,446.16) / 2 = 14,100,223.08  
• Ratio = 5,064,939.23 ÷ 14,100,223.08 ≈ 0.3596, rounded to 0.36  

Step 4. Debt to Equity Ratio  
• Formula: (Total Liabilities) ÷ (Total Owner's Equity)  
• In our balance sheet, the only liabilities given are the current liabilities, which is 1,493,246.99  
• Total Owner's Equity at end = 13,707,199.17  
• Ratio = 1,493,246.99 ÷ 13,707,199.17 ≈ 0.1089, rounded to 0.11  

Thus, the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio": "5.47",
    "operating cash flow ratio": "-0.04",
    "operating cash flow to current liabilities ratio": "-0.04",
    "Total Asset Turnover Ratio": "0.36",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.11"
  }
}
